title: 111_hr5779
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Reduce and End our Deficits Using Commonsense Eliminations in the Agriculture Program Act". The table of contents of this Act is as follows: The "Reduce and End our Deficits Using Commonsense Eliminations in the Agriculture Program Act" includes termination of various federal programs such as commodity storage payments for cotton and peanut producers, Forest Service Economic Action Program, grants for worsted wool fabric manufacturers, Department of Agriculture health care services program for the Delta region, energy efficiency grants and loans in rural communities, and adjusted gross income limitations for certain payments. The "Reduce and End our Deficits Using Commonsense Eliminations in the Agriculture Program Act" includes termination of various federal programs such as commodity storage payments for cotton and peanut producers, Forest Service Economic Action Program, grants for worsted wool fabric manufacturers, Department of Agriculture health care services program for the Delta region, energy efficiency grants and loans in rural communities, and adjusted gross income limitations for certain payments. The act also imposes new limits on payments to producers of certain agricultural commodities, reduces payment acres for commodity programs, funding for market access program, reimbursement rate paid to private insurance companies under crop insurance program, and prohibits timber sales in specific regions of the National Forest System. SEC. 2. Termination of federal commodity storage payments for cotton and peanut producers. Amends sections in the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 to remove subsidies for cotton and peanuts.

SEC. 3. Termination of Forest Service Economic Action Program. The Secretary of Agriculture will end the program providing assistance to rural communities using forest resources.

SEC. 4. Termination of grants to manufacturers of worsted wool fabrics. Ends the authority to provide financial support to wool fabric manufacturers. SEC. 5. Termination of Department of Agriculture health care services program for the Delta region. SEC. 6. Termination of authority to provide energy generation, transmission, and distribution facilities efficiency grants and loans in rural communities with extremely high energy costs. SEC. 7. Revised adjusted gross income limitations for receipt of direct payments, counter-cyclical payments, marketing loan gains, loan deficiency payments, and other agricultural payments or benefits. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to adjust non-farm income limitations for commodity programs. The income limits vary from $500,000 to $250,000 depending on the crop year. Additionally, farm income limitations for direct payments are also adjusted. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to adjust non-farm income limitations for conservation programs. The income limits vary from $750,000 to $500,000 depending on the crop year. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to adjust non-farm income limitations for conservation programs, with limits ranging from $1,000,000 to $750,000 depending on the crop year. The Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to adjust non-farm income limitations for conservation programs, with limits ranging from $1,000,000 to $750,000 depending on the crop year and subsequent years. SEC. 8. New limits on payments to producers of certain agricultural commodities. New limits on payments to producers of certain agricultural commodities: Direct payments and counter-cyclical payments for covered commodities and peanuts are reduced from $40,000 to $20,000 and from $65,000 to $32,500 respectively. The limits on counter-cyclical payments under the Food Security Act of 1985 are reduced from $65,000 to $32,500. SEC. 9. ONE PERCENT REDUCTION IN PAYMENT ACRES FOR COMMODITY PROGRAMS. The amendment to Section 1001 of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 defines 'payment acres' for direct payments for different crop years. The amendment to Section 1301 of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 defines 'payment acres' for counter-cyclical payments for different crop years. The term 'payment acres' for direct and counter-cyclical payments is defined based on the percentage of base acres of peanuts on a farm for different crop years. For direct and counter-cyclical payments, the percentage of base acres of peanuts on a farm varies for different crop years. In 2011 and 2012, 84 percent of base acres are eligible for counter-cyclical payments. The Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 is amended to reduce funding for the Market Access Program from $200,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to $200,000,000 for 2008 through 2010, and $160,000,000 for 2011 and 2012. Additionally, there is a reduction in the reimbursement rate paid to private insurance companies under the crop insurance program. Section 508(k) of the Federal Crop Insurance Act is amended to adjust the percentage of premium used to define loss ratio for different reinsurance years. Subparagraph (E) is removed and redesignated as subparagraph (E). In Section 508(k) of the Federal Crop Insurance Act, subparagraphs (A) through (E) are adjusted to (A) through (D). SEC. 12 prohibits timber sales in certain regions of the National Forest System where federal expenditures for sales exceed offsetting receipts until Congress is certified that sales will generate enough receipts to cover costs.
